docs.lead_paragraph: IT is 12:03 P.M., Saturday, on the 17th floor of the CBS building on West 52d Street, and the Ingram mess, as Dan Ingram himself calls it, has begun to spread out for 60 miles on the FM band. The familiar beat of a 1965 Four Tops recording can be heard on the studio speakers. Mr. Ingram clears his throat, opens the microphone and speaks over the music: "This is the song of the midget and the smorgasbord, "I Can't Help Myself."

headline.main: 'Hi-yo, Kemo Sabe!' A King of Nostalgia
headline.kicker: ON THE AIR WITH DAN INGRAM

docs.lead_paragraph: IN the course of human events, sandwiches have been maligned and exalted, have been delicate contrivances and overstuffed plebian affairs, alternately objects of desire and objects of scorn. Either way, summer is high sandwich season. It is the season of hot dogs at the ball park, hamburgers by the backyard grill and French bread, pate and cheese at picnics -- and now, of leaner, post-modern constructions that rely more on roasted or marinated vegetables than meat and that stylishly recycle leftovers like grilled vegetables, lamb, chicken or fish.

headline.main: Build a Better Sandwich and . . . Yes! It's In!

docs.lead_paragraph: This is a Mother's Day story about a drug with a tongue-twister name. It's called diethylstilbestrol, or DES. Those of us who were affected by it were Flavor-of-the-Month about 20 years ago, when doctors discovered that the synthetic estrogen given to millions of women to prevent miscarriage caused vaginal cancer in some of their female offspring.
